headline: What JD Vance's victory could mean for the Trump-era GOP
author: Conn Carroll
sentences: If Vance wins but Oz and Perdue fail, it will show that Republicans have embraced some of Trump's ideological influence, but that Trump's personal hold on Republicans has limits  and also that an "America First" populism could dominate the GOP long after Trump has run his last campaign.
It is still early in the primary season, but yesterday's result in Ohio was a huge win for former President Donald Trump's continued control of the Republican Party.
His campaign has not focused on the 2020 election result but on the points that helped Trump win in 2016  immigration, trade, and an "America First" foreign policy.
Vance, beat anti-Trump candidate Matt Dolan and former-state Treasurer Josh Mandel, despite millions spent on ads against him by the Club for Growth.
If Trump's candidates sweep these three races, there will be no avoiding the conclusion that Trump has a personal lock on the Republican Party.
But if Oz's celebrity-based campaign falters, and Perdue's 2020 grievance campaign fails to turn out voters, where does that leave the party?
On May 17, Pennsylvania Republicans will choose between Trump-endorsed television star Mehmet Oz and retired Army Ranger David McCormick.
Then, on May 24, Georgia will hold its gubernatorial contest between the Trump-endorsed former Sen. David Perdue and incumbent Gov.
Trump hates Kemp because of his refusal to go along with Trump's claims that he won the 2020 election but that it was stolen.
Vance has always been a critic of the Republican establishment, which he believes was not doing enough for working families.
Looking at Vance's late surge to the top, it is clear that Trump's endorsement was absolutely necessary for Vance's win.
But he has been entirely consistent on issues since his book Hillbilly Elegy made him famous.
Vance has clearly changed his opinion of Trump, whom he once openly loathed.
The candidate Trump endorsed in a highly competitive primary, author J.D.
This race is almost entirely about the 2020 presidential election.
We might find out as the primary calendar unfolds.
But was it the only reason Vance won?
